newsitem.title: INDIA: India gilt yields steady in brisk trade, call flat.
newsitem.headline: India gilt yields steady in brisk trade, call flat.

text.p: Indian call money ended Monday in the 9.0-9.25 percent range, slightly down from the day's opening 9.0-9.75 percent, dealers said.
Good demand for funds kept call rates above nine percent despite expectations that liquidity with banks would improve further, they said.
The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) is expected to reduce banks' cash reserve requirements in its monetary policy scheduled for release on October 19. This is expected to improve liquidity with banks.
Dealers said there was brisk secondary market trading in government securities on Monday but there was little change in yields. "Prices were largely stable," said a dealer.
"Some market participants are taking positions in short and medium dated securities anticipating easy money conditions after the monetary policy is announced on October 19."
The 13.50 percent 1997 stock was traded at 12.70 percent against 12.69 at the weekend while the 13.50 percent 1998 was traded unchanged at 13.16 percent.

Dealers said there was little activity in commercial paper and certificates of deposit. Rates on intercorporate deposits remained steady in the 18.0-20.0 perent range for top-rated borrowers, they said.
